awd_titl_txt: CAREER: The Rational Design of Plasmonic Photocatalysts for Efficient Solar Energy Conversion
awd_abstract_narration:
TECHNICAL SUMMARY

The Solid State and Materials Chemistry Program of the Division of Materials Research will support the research and education program of Prof. Wei David Wei at the University of Florida.  Prof. Wei's group will develop methods and strategies to address key questions concerning surface plasmon resonance (SPR)-mediated electron transfer (SPMET) in order to develop new materials and strategies for efficient solar-to-chemical energy conversion.  The developed methods will allow the direct probing of the spatial distribution, diffusion mechanics, and relaxation dynamics of the "effective hot electrons" following the SPMET process at the single-nanoparticle level. The proposed fundamental study will clarify the specific role of SPR in enhancing photocatalytic activity, and the obtained knowledge will lay the groundwork for the design and construction of novel plasmonic heterostructures for highly efficient solar photocatalysis.  These unique SPR-mediated ET strategies will be essential to a number of related energy conversion and storage processes where ET and transport play important roles, and they will further inform the development of technologies that improve upon the low efficiency endemic to many contemporary methods of photocatalytic chemical energy production.  Moreover, these strategies will advance many other technologically-relevant areas, not covered in this proposal, that exploit photoinduced redox reactions, ranging from organic chemistry to biochemistry.

NON-TECHNICAL SUMMARY

Discoveries from this project will lead to new materials and technologies that promote the cleaner energy and healthier environment that are vital to the nation's future.  The broader educational impact of this program will be the instruction and inspiration of the next generation of scientists, particularly in the field of solar energy.  Prof. Wei and his group will specifically focus on broadening the participation of groups underrepresented in the sciences.  In conjunction with student mentorship and curriculum development, Prof. Wei will continue his previous efforts to implement several outreach activities to educate high school students, teachers, and the general public on nanomaterials for solar photocatalysis.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

por.por_cntn:
Intellectual Merit: the scientific goal of this CAREER project was to address key questions concerning surface plasmon resonance (SPR)-mediated electron transfer (ET) in order to develop new materials and strategies for efficient solar-to-chemical energy conversion. We have developed methods to directly probe the spatial distribution, diffusion mechanics, and relaxation dynamics of the plasmon-generated "effective hot electrons" at the single-nanoparticle level.  Furthermore, we used the obtained knowledge to inform the development of strategies for the rational design and construction of plasmonically active hybrid nanostructures optimized for absorbing visible light and retaining electrons available for surface reactions.

Broader Impacts: the project has included three postdoctoral research associates, eight chemistry graduate students, ten undergraduate students, and eleven high school students. Among them fourteen are female students, three are Hispanic students, two are African-American students, and one is LGBTQ student. To date, there have been one book chapter, twelve peer-reviewed journal articles (Chemical Reviews, Energy & Environmental Science, Angewandte Chemie International Edition, JACS, Advanced Materials, Advanced Energy Materials), four manuscripts in review, one invited review that will be submitted in the next three months (Accounts of Chemical Research), and twenty-three invited presentations based on the work for this project.

Public Outreach: In conjunction with the University of Florida public radio station WUFT-FM, this project produced the radio series Tiny Tech, which is a set of 90-second radio modules devoted to the chemistry of nanotechnology. To date, total 5 different episodes had been aired. Audio (mp3) files and the scripts are available in the archives at tinytechradio.org. The archive can also be reached through the local programming link at http://www.wuftfm.org/.

Students have continuously participated in the UF Chemistry Department's Halloween Molecular Mania: Chemistry Day at the Oaks Mall. In collaboration with the outreach project of Prof. Adam Veige (University of Florida), this free event featured interactive demonstrations designed to convey chemistry concepts to the youth of our community. The PI's team demonstrations included Au nanoparticles and electrodeposition of metals on coins. Even during the pandemic period, our group has successfully developed the online version demonstrations for this event.

 


Last Modified: 12/06/2021
Modified by: Wei Wei
